quiz.title: Unit 5: Energy & Power (Quiz 1)
quiz.subtitle: Work, Kinetic Energy, and Potential Energy (12 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Energy Fundamentals and Basic Energy Calculations

questions.question: What is the scientific definition of work?
options: Force applied over a distance in the direction of force
questions.explanation: Work is defined as force applied through a distance in the direction of the force: W = F × d × cosθ.

questions.question: A 10 N force pushes a box 5 meters horizontally. How much work is done?
questions.explanation: Work = Force × distance = 10 N × 5 m = 50 J

questions.question: Which scenario demonstrates NO work being done?
questions.explanation: No work is done when there is no displacement, even if force is applied.

questions.question: What is the kinetic energy of a 2 kg object moving at 4 m/s?
questions.explanation: KE = ½mv² = ½ × 2 kg × (4 m/s)² = 1 × 16 = 16 J

questions.question: How does kinetic energy change when velocity doubles?
questions.explanation: KE depends on v², so doubling velocity quadruples kinetic energy.

questions.question: A 5 kg object has 40 J of kinetic energy. What is its speed?
questions.explanation: KE = ½mv² → 40 = ½ × 5 × v² → v² = 16 → v = 4 m/s

questions.question: What type of energy is stored in a stretched spring?
questions.explanation: Stretched or compressed springs store elastic potential energy.

questions.question: What is the gravitational potential energy of a 3 kg object 4 meters above the ground?
questions.explanation: GPE = mgh = 3 kg × 9.8 m/s² × 4 m = 117.6 J

questions.question: When does an object have maximum gravitational potential energy?
questions.explanation: GPE increases with height, so maximum at the highest point.

questions.question: A person holds a 20 N box 1.5 m above the floor. How much work did they do against gravity?
questions.explanation: Work against gravity = weight × height = 20 N × 1.5 m = 30 J

questions.question: Which has more kinetic energy: a 1000 kg car at 10 m/s or a 2000 kg car at 5 m/s?
What happens to the work done if the angle between force and displacement increases from 0° to 90°?
questions.explanation: Work = Fd cosθ; as θ increases from 0° to 90°, cosθ decreases from 1 to 0, so work decreases.
